Restatement of the issue

The concern is that the essay treated the development of medieval systematic theology almost exclusively through individual theologians and methods (Anselm, Abelard, Lombard, Aquinas), but neglected conciliar and quasi‑confessional documents, especially in the late medieval period (for example, the Council of Florence), which gave dogmatically normative formulations on grace, justification, the sacraments, and ecclesiology that then shaped and constrained later systematics. From a Reformed confessional standpoint, these documents matter both as background to the Reformation and as witnesses to trajectories the Reformers would later contest.

Historical setting and nature of late medieval “confessional” texts

In the high and late Middle Ages, doctrinal development did not occur only in university theology but also in:

  • Ecumenical and union councils (Lyons II 1274; Florence 1438–45).
  • Anti‑heretical councils and papal bulls (e.g., Fourth Lateran 1215; Benedictus Deus 1336; Unigenitus 1343).
  • Canon law collections in which conciliar and papal determinations were codified and treated as normative.

These texts functioned quasi‑confessionally within Latin Christendom:

  • They defined orthodoxy over against heresy (e.g., Albigensians, Waldensians, Hussites).
  • They provided binding doctrinal determinations for clergy, theologians, and universities.
  • They furnished fixed loci (on grace, merit, sacraments, ecclesial authority) that late scholastic systematics would presuppose and elaborate.

The Council of Florence as a doctrinal milestone

The Council of Florence is especially important because it attempted doctrinal reunion with Eastern churches while also stabilizing Western sacramental and soteriological teaching.

Key determinations relevant to systematics include:

  • On the sacraments (Decretum pro Armenis). Florence defined seven sacraments; specified their “matter” and “form”; affirmed their causality (sacraments confer grace ex opere operato in the properly disposed); and articulated the necessity of baptism and penance in a way that structurally supports a sacramental‑penitential system of justification.
  • On justification and merit. Florence continued and codified a trajectory visible from Lateran IV and the anti‑Pelagian determinations of earlier councils but with a distinct late medieval coloration:
    • Grace as a created habit infused into the soul, yielding an inherent righteousness.
    • Cooperation of free will with prevenient grace as normative, not exceptional.
    • Increase of justification through good works meritorious de condigno because rooted in charity infused by grace.
  • On ecclesiology and authority. The council presupposed and strengthened papal primacy and jurisdiction; its decrees were framed as authoritative determinations of the Roman church for all Christians, functioning de facto as universal dogmatic norms in the West.

These doctrinal determinations became baseline assumptions for Thomist, Scotist, and nominalist systems in the later 15th and early 16th centuries. Systematic theology in the schools did not merely develop from the Sentences and Aristotle; it developed under the binding force of conciliar decisions like Florence that had delimited acceptable positions.

  • The Reformed denial of justification by infused righteousness directly challenges the Florentine and Tridentine construal of grace and merit.
  • The Reformed insistence on two sacraments, instituted by Christ and defined primarily by Word‑promise rather than Aristotelian “matter and form,” stands against the sacramental system codified at Florence and completed at Trent.
  • The Reformed subordination of councils to Scripture, and denial that even ecumenical councils can bind consciences beyond Scripture, directly contests the late medieval practice of treating councils like Florence as dogmatically definitive in themselves.

Without reference to these late medieval “confessional” norms, the Reformed reaction can appear to be merely intra‑scholastic rather than also a rejection of a juridically imposed doctrinal structure.
